titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The french Ambassador paid me a morning visit, and told me that he would come and dine with us to-morrow. He mentioned that he had heard I was going away; and intended to return to the United States— I told him I should probably not go the present year— I said I had heard also that he was going away; and that he was to take the Department of foreign affairs at Paris— He said that he had been here three years, and that the report had been constantly circulated during the whole time that he was going away— That as to the Department of foreign Affairs, it was not at all desirable that he should have it— My walk this day was shortened, and I employed the Evening writing and reading.

2. Mr: Dana called upon me this morning to enquire concerning the state of his business— I told him of the interview I had last with Baron Campenhausen, and what I expected from it— And I desired him to send me a written statement of the case upon which I would draw up a note to Count Romanzoff.— We had Company this day at dinner— The french Ambassador— Count Schenk the Minister from the king of Wurtemburg, and Baron Mülinen his Secretary— Baron Blome Minister of Denmark and Chevalier Krabbe his Secretary— Count Bussche, Minister of the king of Westphalia— General Watzdorf, of the king of Saxony, and General Pardo, of the king of Spain— General Betancourt his Lady and two daughters— Count Luxbourg, Chargé d’Affaires from the king of Bavaria, and the three Secretaries of the french Embassy, Rayneval, Prevost and Rumigny— After dinner Mr: Rayneval played at the Piano and sung. Miss Clementine de Bode was here in the Evening. Baron Mülinen informed us that he had obtained his recall, and should go in three weeks or a Month; with the hope of being placed at Vienna or at Paris.

3. The weather is so mild that it would seem as if the Spring was about to set in, and the passage of the streets begins to be bad— I had this day no interruption of company, and employed my time in writing and reading— There was however a dissipation of Spirits unfavourable to application; and a heaviness in the Evening, which produced a necessary idleness— I read Massillon’s Discourse to his Clergy upon the Communion— Not of much value— It is in the most affected Style of his quaint scriptural applications— The division is proper—on the dispositions suitable for partaking the Sacrament, and on the fruits to be derived from it. But after announcing this partition he says that for shortness sake he shall treat only of the first part— In the Evening I read Robinson’s Character of John the Baptist. There is a panegyric of Massillon upon this same Saint, which I read last October— Robinson makes much less of the subject than the Bishop. I intermitted my usual Evening’s writing— Masson’s remarks upon Russian Education were not lively enough to keep me awake.

4. I was confined all this day to the house by continual rain; I employed it principally in writing— Mr: Smith dined abroad— I resumed the writing of short hand this Evening— It is about four months since I began to practice it, and I find that it begins to grow familiar to me— More than twenty years I have had the knowledge of this mode of writing, and have neglected it when I might have made it most eminently useful to me. It is one of the great instances in which I have lost advantages by the want of perseverance.— I had a visit this morning from a Mr David, a frenchman who is a naturalized Citizen of the United States— In the Evening we had Cards.

5. I paid a morning visit to Mr: Hollins and Mr: Saltus at the Hotel de l’Europe, a new public house, opened a few weeks since on the Winter Palace Square, opposite the Admiralty, and kept by our old Landlord of the Hotel de Londres, Tardif— I found with them a Mr: Wallace of New-York, who was introduced to me— Mr: Coxe who lodges at the same house was not at home— I invited them all to dine with us on Thursday.— I then went to Ray’s Hotel to see Mr: Dana, and to Mr: Meyer’s on the Island; but both those Gentlemen were abroad— I returned home by my customary walk— My object was to make inquiries concerning the state of the vessels, not yet admitted, and for which I have resolved to make another application to Count Romanzoff— I therefore wrote him a note to request to see him. In the Evening I wrote, and read Bossuet’s Discourse.— I find myself in my first sketch running into a barren detail of insipid facts— If I cannot as the work advances throw some interest into it, by interspersing reflections or characters in the narrative, the best thing I can do when it is finished will be to commit it to the flames.

6. Took my long walk this morning before breakfast; and again a short one just before dinner. Mr: Smith dined abroad. We closed the Evening with Cards; but I had been reading and writing untill ten O’Clock— I finished the Original Discourse upon Universal History— There is to the Edition which Mr: Navarro has lent me a Continuation, said to have been written by Bossuet; but never published untill the year 1806.— This work which I had never read untill now, has been and still is so excessively extolled by the French writers, that as usually happens to overrated things it has not answered my expectations— Bossuet was a party writer (in regard to religion) and the reputation of all such authors is exaggerated and partly factitious— Faction of every kind can find wit in dulness and supernatural powers in ordinary genius— The discourse however is not an ordinary work. It is a bold and vigorous outline of Universal History; chiefly founded upon the Bible— The succession of Empires is marked out by a series of remarkable epochs, and the Fortunes of the People of God, and their Successors the Christian Church are compressed into a small but interesting abridgment. There are some Chronological discussions not very clearly elucidated—a review of the prophecies, equally profound and ingenious— An exposition of the arguments of the Jews who deny the application of the prophecies to Jesus Christ and an argumentation against the Protestants derived from the novelty of their Sects. The Bishop’s tone whenever he enters upon Controversy, has nothing in it of Christian humility or charity— He is arrogant and insulting; as when he speaks of Louis 14. he is a base and servile flatterer. He concludes with a rapid view of the Roman History in which he recognizes the love of Liberty and the Spirit of Patriotism, as the sources of all their greatness— This Book was written for the Dauphin the Son of Louis, the author having been one of his Instructors.

7. I had yesterday an answer from Count Romanzoff to my note, appointing this Evening, at 8 O’Clock to meet me at his House upon the Quay— This morning I received a second note from him, with excuses for postponing the time of receiving my visit untill to-morrow at Noon when he would receive me at the Hotel des Affaires Etrangères; by which I understood the Public Building on the Quay. I drew up a minute of the Cases of American vessels concerning which the decision is yet delayed; to deliver to him.— Walked before dinner to the foundery— Mr: Dana & Mr: Plummer, with Messrs: Hollins, Saltus, Coxe and Wallis dined with us; and also spent part of the Evening here— We closed it with cards— I began reading the Continuation of Bossuet’s Discourse.

8. A Mr: Sonntag an American Citizen, and who has been a naval Officer (sailing Master) in the service of the United States, called upon me this morning and informed me that he had the intention of entering the Russian service.— He went from this City two or three months ago; intending then as he told me to go to Odessa; upon commercial pursuits— He went however no farther than Moscow, and has now returned here with this new project. I mentioned to him the case of Mr: Jewett, who was here the last Summer with a similar intention; but failed of success in his application— Mr: Sonntag said he had no apprehension of any difficulty in his application— That they wanted Officers for their vessels on the Black Sea, and that the English Officers whom they had would not serve— I asked if he had already had any encouragement from the Government— He said he had yesterday seen the Marquis de Traversey the Minister of the Marine, and had no doubt of success— Perhaps the Marquis might apply to me to certify that he was an American, and had been in the Service of the United States; for which reason he had brought me his Commission, which he shewed me— It is signed by President Jefferson, and dated in August 1807. I asked him if he considered himself authorized to enter a foreign service without first having his discharge from that of the United States— He said that he could shew me his furlough, which was for as long a time as he pleased, and authorized him to dispose of himself as he pleased— That he had already once lost his claim to promotion in the Navy by a furlough, and had been obliged to re-enter the service in the rank at which he had left it, while officers below him had been advanced; and that he had lately received a letter from his father which informed him that he was considered as no longer in the service. He had told me when he was here before that his furlough was unlimited in regard to time; but that it left him his rank in the service, and the obligation to return to it whenever the Government might call upon him— I reminded him of this; but he said he had since received the letter from his father stating that he was no longer in the service— I asked him if he was aware of the Article of Amendment to the Constitution which had duly pass’d by a sufficient majority of both
Houses of Congress, and which may now have become a part of the Constitution; by force of which any Citizen of the United States would forfeit his rights and character as such by accepting a Commission in the service of any foreign sovereign, without first obtaining the consent of Congress— He said he had not seen it; but at any rate he did not think it could apply to him, as he could have no notice of it as part of the Constitution at the time of his engaging in the service of Russia— I offered to shew it to him; but he said that it would not alter his determination— I then observed that I mentioned it to him, because I might be obliged to consider it as a rule of conduct for myself— The Marquis de Traversey had required of Mr: Jewett that he should produce a sort of recommendatory certificate from me— If he should require nothing of that kind now from him, I should have no occasion to interfere in the case, and of course should have nothing to do with it— But if he should ask for such a certificate, I should be desirous of rendering him Mr: Sonntag any service in my power to promote his views, as far as was consistent with my own duty— That I did not personally approve of the principle of the proposed Amendment to the Constitution, but if adopted it would be a law which I should be bound to observe, and must conduct myself conformably to it. If I was to certify that he was discharged from the service of the United States, I must have some Evidence to warrant the Certificate— I could otherwise only certify that he considered himself as discharged— He said he did not suppose that any thing more would be desired of me than to attest that he was an American Citizen, which I assured him I would do with pleasure— At 12. O’Clock, I went to the Office of the Department of foreign Affairs on the Quay of the Neva, which I supposed to be the place where Count Romanzoff had appointed to meet me; but he was not there— I then went to his own house on the Quay; but did not find him— I finally went to the House where he resides and was admitted— On apologizing to him for being so late, and telling him that I had first gone to the Office of the Department, which I thought his note had indicated to me, he said that the house in which he lives was the Hotel des Affaires Etrangères— I then told him the subject upon which I had requested to see him— The vessels which were still waiting for a decision respecting the whole, or parts of their Cargoes— He expressed some surprize; and said he thought that business had already been settled some time ago. I said it had been in part; but that there remained a number concerning which it had been delayed— That not wishing to importune him more than was absolutely necessary, I had applied several times directly to Baron Campenhausen concerning it— That he had repeatedly assured me, that the business should be immediately settled in their favour, but it was not yet done— I then told him how long this decision had been delayed, and how important it was to those concerned that they should have time to transact their business, and be able to get away immediately on the opening of the Navigation in the Spring— I added that I had made a minute in writing of all the cases, not in official form, but merely as a Memorandum, which with his permission I would give him— He said he was very glad I had brought it, as it would serve him to draw up his official note to Baron Campenhausen, which he would immediately send— He would not call this delay a caprice of the Baron’s, but he did not know what was the reason of it.— I accordingly delivered the minute to him, and mentioned particularly the case of the Eliza at Archangel, repeating to him the observations which I made concerning her last week to Baron Campenhausen— I asked the Count’s permission to send him a packet to be forwarded by the first Courier that would go to Paris— He said that he would send it with pleasure; that he had already received notice of a Courier from Paris, whom he expected immediately, and shortly after his arrival he should dispatch one.— He asked me if I had any news from England— I had none— He said it appeared Mr: Labouchère the same person who had been sent to London last Winter from Holland was gone again; but as there had been no change of Ministry, probably he would be as little listened to as he was before— Perhaps he had been sent upon the expectation that with the establishment of the Regency there would have been a new set of Ministers.— I said that I should have supposed the subject upon which Mr Labouchère went last Winter was now no longer a matter for Negotiation, as Holland had been so formally annexed to the French Empire— Pourquoi pas? said the Count; such things are not irrevocable; and at least the Emperor Napoleon may be willing to offer terms which may be favorable to England— I said that as to the restoration of the kingdom of Holland, I did not think that was an object in which the English Government would take much interest—they would be indifferent as to the form of a Government which must essentially be under the absolute controul of France— He said he thought so too, and although it might not be an agreeable consideration for the Hollanders, it was impossible to conceal that they were no longer to be prized as they formerly had been, considered as a Nation— I asked the Count if this was a special
Holiday, having seen a great number of Carriages and Sledges in the St: Isaac’s Square, before the Church, and several Soldiers at the Church door— He said it was no Holiday; but as the nobility of the Province had been this week making their Elections, perhaps it was some religious ceremony which they attended at the close of the business. He had heard that Count Strogonoff had been re-elected the first marshall— It was the eighth time that he had been elected—that is he had held the Office ever since the establishment of the system; which was an Institution of the Empress Catherine— But as it was not to be disguised that Count Strogonoff was growing old, they had now elected a Candidate, who he heard was Count Orloff, as a substitute in case of a vacancy— He had not attended, and had never attended these meetings himself, because he did not consider himself as having a right to attend them— There were indeed many persons who attended them merely because they were owners of a House in St: Petersburg; but that was not the Construction which he gave to the law— At the first Election, the Empress Catherine to avoid every appearance or even suspicion of exercising any influence had purposely left the City and gone upon a Journey while the Elections were held. At present, our Masters, said the Count, do not absent themselves at these times, but as to this Province, the Institution itself has not answered the expectations that had been entertained from it— The object was to assemble in a body and make a representation of the principal land holders— But from the situation of the Capital, and of the property in its neighbourhood it turns out that all the owners of the petty gardens and Country seats on the Peterhof road claimed the right of attending the meetings here; and upon such a title, one of the Marshals elected was a Mr: Bille, the brother of a Merchant in this City— A man who to be sure as a merchant had a very respectable occupation, and was wealthy; but who had begun lower in life than that.— The Count therefore is not much satisfied with the Institution, which is indeed a singular anomaly in a Government like this— The Elections are held once every three years; and the Merchants have an Election separate from that of the nobility.— The Officers elected constitute the judicial tribunals of the Province, from which there is an appeal to the Senate— My conference with the Count was short, and I left him about 1. O’Clock— In the Evening we had visits from Mr: Rumigny, and afterwards from Mr: Hollins and Mr: Saltus— The french Ambassador received a Courier this morning.

9. Mr: Montréal called on me this Morning, and I enquired of him if he knew of a meeting among the merchants, the object of which is to petition the Emperor to grant licences for vessels to come here with Colonial Merchandize— He had heard nothing of it, he went from my house to the Ambassador’s, where he only saw Mr: Rayneval— He returned here in about half an hour, and told me that the Ambassador had received his recall— That he was to be succeeded by General Lauriston an Aid de Camp of the Emperor Napoleon, who it was expected would leave Paris to come here in April— He promised to make further enquiries about this petition of the merchants, and give me information if he obtains any.— Mr: Fisher also paid me a visit with Mr: Fellowes a Young Man from Boston, who has spent most of the winter at Revel. I enclosed this morning two letters for my brother under cover to Mr: Forbes.

10. Mr: Montréal came again this morning, and gave me an Account of an hour’s conversation, which he had just been having with the Ambassador, who he says is all mildness and moderation, and utterly averse to a War with Russia— He told him that he had heard a week ago of this intended petition from the merchants— He should have a copy of it, and would shew it to him when it came. That he did not see what objection they could make against it, as its intention was to propose merely to follow the example of France— He dwelt with great earnestness on the evils and the dangers of a War with Russia; which he said would prove a second Spanish War— Spoke of the Spanish War, as of a most exhausting and ruinous thing— Remarked how exasperated the Russian nobility and Nation were against France; and said that the Emperor Napoleon had been deceived, about the decree for burning the English merchandizes— That decree had not done any harm to the English; but it had been the cause of the great number of heavy bankruptcies upon the Continent which have been incessantly succeeding one another since its adoption— He spoke about the American vessels here—asked Montréal whether some of those which came under American Colours had not been confiscated, and said he had heard that two or three of those, which I strongly claimed, were in doubtful circumstances: Montréal assured him that not one American vessel had been confiscated, and that he was convinced every one that I had claimed was a genuine American— He said nothing to Montréal about his own recall, whence he concludes that he is not much gratified by it. He says the Ambassador is a man of most violent temper, and sometimes loses all controul over it—of which he gave me an instance in a transaction with which he himself had
some concern— I never saw any manifestation of this sort in him— I had afterwards a visit from the Chevalier Lebzeltern the Austrian Counsellor of Legation, who lately arrived— He came to make some enquiries concerning a certain Countess Lubomirska, a Polish lady, who was guillotined during the most atrocious period of the French Revolution, but of whom it had lately been pretended that she had escaped; had married an American Minister who was then in France, and was now in America. This tale had excited the anxiety of her family— He had written to Paris to enquire the name of the American Minister alluded to, and on receiving the answer he should write me a note requesting me to obtain decisive information as to the facts— I promised him to make any enquiry that he should desire, and told him that the Minister at that in time in France was Mr: Morris, but that he had not married a Polish Lady; and untill very lately had not been married at-all— He told me that he was born in Portugal, and mentioned a number of Americans with whom he had been acquainted— Mr: Smith of S. Carolina, while he was Minister in Portugal— Lady Temple— and Genl Armstrong—who he said was very much respected at Paris, and had entirely fixed the public opinion.— He had seen him at Court last September, just before he left France to return home— That he had always lived in a very retired manner, and scarcely ever appeared at Court— That time however he had been, and was treated with very marked and particular distinction by the Emperor Napoleon; and it was the more noticed because it was immediately after the excellent Note which he had written to Monsieur de Champagny, which had been universally admired for its Spirit and Independence, had been published.— I told him that I had reason to think that the Emperor Napoleon had by no means felt himself flattered by that Note— He said that was well known, and was the very reason why his distinction of Genl: Armstrong was so remarkable— He then said that we were about to lose one of the members of the Corps Diplomatique here— The Ambassador was recalled. I asked him if he thought he was going, to be Minister of Foreign Affairs— No—he did not believe it— What then could be the motive for his recall?— perhaps a change in the state of the relations between the two Countries—a change of tone in the Negotiations— A new organ of Communication was sometimes convenient— A person after residing in a place some time formed connections, which made him less fit to hold a particular language. I told him I had heard that of late there was a softening in the discussions between France and Russia— That they were approaching to a better understanding with each other— He shook his head, and said that he sincerely wished it might be so—but intimated he had his doubts as to the fact. These visits occupied almost all the morning— The rest of the day I walked, read and wrote as usual. Read Massillon’s Sermon upon the zeal incumbent upon the priesthood against vices— He enumerates the causes which contribute to slacken this zeal, and prompt them to blameable indulgence— their own corruptions— respect of persons— diffidence of themselves &c— The passage in which he warns them against flattery & obsequiousness to the great is excellent— I also read two Sections of Robinson’s Character of Jesus-Christ— It is strictly trinitarian; and refers to several books in defence of the Nicene Creed. I question whether there is any thing more powerful than Massillon’s Sermon.

11. Mr. Charles Gramman paid me a visit this morning, and informed me that Mr: Lohman had concluded not to go untill the opening of the Navigation. In walking my usual round this morning I met the Emperor upon the Fontanka— He stop’d, and talked about the weather— Said it was very windy, and that I was in the direction to have it shortly afterwards in the face— I told him that as it was not cold, and I had already been walking long enough to quicken the circulations, I should scarcely perceive the wind— I asked him whether this very warm weather which has now continued nearly a fortnight would not break up the river.— He said that it would be a very extraordinary instance if it did— That the river had never been known to break up before the middle of March; and sometimes not untill May— I observed that the last year it had waited untill the 30th: of April; but I thought it could not stand so long this Season— But, said he, we shall be paid for all this moderate weather before the winter ends— The Spring never begins before its time, without relapsing afterwards into winter— Even last year, on the 31st: of May, our Style, think of that, our Style, I was going to Twer, and had on the road a very considerable flight of Snow. We gain nothing by having mild weather too soon— While he was in the midst of these remarks, a Carriage and four pass’d us in the Street— He step’d aside from before me—put up his glass to see who was in the Carriage; bowed and took off his hat, and then step’d back to me, and finished the sentence which he had broken off in the middle— I continued my walk and soon afterwards met Count Lüxbourg, who walked with me to the Corner of the Winter-Palace.— He spoke to me of the Ambassador’s recall, and said he had pass’d an hour with him yesterday conversing with him on the subject. From his language to Lüxbourg, is to be inferred exactly the same as from his Conversation with Montréal— It is precisely in the same Spirit. He did not tell Lüxbourg that he had requested his own
recall; but insinuated, that the climate was too severe for his health— That he had written of the attack he had of illness on the New-Year’s day— That it was necessary for him not to be too long absent from a new Court at home; so that he might have an opportunity to find and keep a suitable station at it. That General Lauriston his successor, was a very good and very moderate man— That the dispositions of the French Government towards that of Russia were altogether friendly and pacific— That his recall was in terms of entire satisfaction with him; that he was left at liberty to take his leave immediately or to wait untill General Lauriston should arrive— That no particular Instructions would be given to the General, as the Duke would be best able to give him on his arrival every necessary direction. I told Lüxbourg that I was very glad to hear this, as the first appearance of so sudden recall of an Ambassador who was so much in favour here, at a time when some sharp discussions between the two Governments had been taking placed looked as if a new person was chosen to assume a different tone; and that this event had occasioned a great sensation here in the public.— He said it was true; and he thought the Ambassador would do well to give out explicitly that he had solicited his own recall— He added that he had heard from another quarter that the Emperor had had a long Conversation with the Ambassador since his recall; and had desired him on his return to France to represent the distress which Russia and all the Continent were suffering by the War; the impossibility for Russia to support it much longer; and to intimate the expediency of undertaking in concert a serious negotiation for a Peace— I asked Lüxbourg whether the Ambassador himself had told this— He said he had not— From what quarter then, said I, can it come, unless from the Emperor himself— He said he had it from Count Stedingk— It is certain that the Ambassador takes pains to circulate the opinion that the views of France are entirely pacific— The Emperor and Count Romanzoff appear not to be alarmed or uneasy at the Ambassador’s recall— Let us wait for the arrival of his successor.— In the Evening and read the Continuation of Bossuet— A mere collection of materials for a Continuation— A Chronological index—dry, tedious, and in some places ridiculous.

12. Visits this morning from the Chevalier de Navarro and from Mr: Fisher with Mr: Dugan— Mr: Sonntag called upon me before breakfast, requesting me for a certificate to the Marquis de Traversey the Minister of the Marine, that he was an American and that he had been an Officer in the American service. I asked him for the evidence of his discharge from the service, and he shewed me a letter from the Secretary of the Navy, dated 25. May 1809. granting him leave of absence from the service, without limitation of time, and observing that he would not be entitled to pay untill called into actual service again— I told him I could not consider that as a discharge— He said that he had once before had a furlough for twelve months, and because he did not return untill three months after the time limited, which was impossible as he had been to the East-Indies, he found himself obliged when he went back to enter the service a new, with only his old rank; while in his absence many Officers had been promoted over him. He said he did not chuse to return again to the service, unless he could have advancement as if he had not been absent. I said that was for him to consider— I should not think myself bound to take any measure to prevent his admission into the Russian service; but to give him a certificate to obtain it I must be satisfied that he was discharged from that of the United States.— He said he must then endeavour to get along with the papers that he had.— Mr: Navarro mentioned to me the arrival of a Russian Courier from Paris yesterday.— Prince Kurakin the Russian Ambassador at Paris was sick. Mr: Nesselrode the first Counsellor of the Embassy, had conferred with the French Minister of foreign Affairs, who had complained to him that the new Russian Tariff manifested so much favour to the English, and was so much opposed to France— Nesselrode had answered that by the Treaties each of the two Governments had reserved to itself the right of making such Tariff and commercial prohibitions as it should see fit. That France had set the example, by prohibiting the importation of Russia leather, and loading Potash with excessive duties— And that there was in the Tariff no favour to the English— As to the remonstrances in favour of the Duke of Oldenburg, the Duke of Cadore said that General Lauriston would be instructed, concerning that— But then it was known that the Emperor Napoleon, upon hearing of the remonstrances had said that what was done, was done— Mr: Dugan belongs to Philadelphia, and is owner of one of the vessels, whose Cargoes are yet not admitted. He thinks his case very hard, and so do all the others.— In the Evening we had a long visit from Mr: Rayneval the first Secretary of the French Embassy, who was full of conversation and very agreeable— I conclude from his talk that the Ambassador had not explicitly requested his recall— He said the Secretaries all expected to stay— General Lauriston is a native of India, and a descendant from the famous Law— Mrs: Adams was unwell all the latter part of the day; and at Night very ill.

13. Morning visits from Mr Plummer who brought with him and introduced to me Mr Baer of New-York, and Mr: Lawrie of Philadelphia—and from Mr: Montréal— I learnt some further particulars respecting the state of the negotiations between the Russian and French Governments— The Russian Courier of whom the Count (Romanzoff) spoke to me, arrived the day before yesterday— I therefore made up my packet for Mr: Russell our Chargé d’Affairs at Paris, and sent it with a note to the Count— I met Mr: Prevost the Secretary of the French Embassy walking, and he asked me to send him back the Comedy of Les deux Gendres which he lent me.— I sent it to him in the Evening— Mrs: Adams continued very unwell the whole day, & was very sick at Night.

14. Count Lüxbourg paid me a morning visit, and I walked with him round the Fontanka, and the River-Quay; where we met Mr Prevost, and he turned and walked with us. Lüxbourg is in great perplexity to know what to portend from this recall of the Ambassador. He wishes the Chevalier de Bray was here to determine what to write about it to his Court. The object is of great interest to these Princes of the Rhenish Confederation, and the aspect of things differs from the tone of the Ambassador’s Conversation. The Ambassador himself paid us a visit in the Evening.— He says his letter of recall mentions that at the time of his receiving it, his successor General Lauriston would be on the road, coming here— So that he expects him in two or three weeks.

15. Mr: Sonntag came and asked me for a certificate that he was an Officer of the American Navy upon furlough, which I gave him on the exhibition of his Commission, and of the letter from the Secretary of the Navy, granting him leave of absence without limitation of time. Madame de Betancourt and her daughters were here in the morning; and Catherine and Charles went and dined at her house— My morning was wasted idly— In the Evening I wrote, and read the second Volume of Bossuet’s Continuation.

16. I had no interruption of visitors this morning, but was engaged in an examination and comparison of the returns for the last four years of the Births, Deaths and Marriages of the Russian Empire, as the foundation for an estimate of its population— I fix it at forty-five millions. I have made an Extract from the Gazettes of it for the Secretary of State; but it has employed most of my morning time, these three days. I dined at Mr: Charles Grammann’s with a Company of about fifty persons, ladies and Gentlemen; Americans, Germans, and Russians.— The Chevalier Navarro was there— A Princess Sherebatoff, whom I and never seen— A German who told me that when I was here before I had lodged in a house belonging to him; (the one on the Quay;) and another who said that he had then belonged to the house of Strahlborn and Wolff, who were then Mr: Dana’s bankers— He said also that he had still some rich Court Clothes, which had been left at that time with him, of which he requested me to dispose— But as I left no Court Clothes here these must belong to Mr: Dana.— The invitations were from Mr: and Mrs: Grammann, and they were to spend the Evening as well as to a dinner— The Evening party was a Ball; but I did not stay to attend it.— Mr: Fisher informed me that Mr: Coxe was going to-morrow, and intended to call upon me this Evening— After I came home however, I received a note from Mr: Fisher, promising to call on me with Mr: Coxe to-morrow-morning.

17. Mr: Fisher called upon me this morning, with Mr: Coxe, who intends going this day or to-morrow for Riga; and thence by the shortest way to Gothenburg— I gave him a couple of Packets for the Secretary of State, and one or two others. In taking my daily walk I met upon the Quay General Pardo, and walked with him— He talked as usual of political news, and of a Courier received by the French Ambassador the day before yesterday; by whom he received a positive order to stay, untill the arrival of Count Lauriston his successor. General Pardo pledges himself that the Ambassador’s recall was at his own repeated solicitations, and that he had told him his health was so impaired that on his arrival at Paris he should ask permission to go to the Waters of Barrége— In the Evening we had a visit from Baron Blome, who likewise talked politics in his style— I asked him some questions concerning this Country, which he could not answer— For the current news of the day, such as is picked up by visits, and such as those with whom he associates incline to circulate, Baron Blome is the best informed man at this Court: But he gets no secret information: is often misinformed, and as to the History and Constitutional organization of the Country quite ignorant— So are all the foreigners whom I meet here. They seldom think it worth their trouble to make inquiries.— I read this day, Massillon’s Sermon upon the Vocation to the Clerical Office, which contains many curious particulars— His plan and divisions of the Discourse are as usual very ingenious, and applied with great address to the text— The signs of Vocation should be similar to those manifested by Jesus himself. The testimony of the Church—of the Public—and of the person’s own Conscience— All the arguments on the second head tend to prove that ordination ought to be founded upon popular election— Though the Bishop acknowledges that this is a heresy. There is a citation from St. Gregory which is almost ludicrous— It accounts for the final reprobation of Saul, because Samuel anointed him only with a vial of oil,
and for the permanent establishment of David and his family upon the throne, because for the purpose of anointing him the prophet was ordered to fill a whole horn with oil. This is one of those quaint conceits, which are such blemishes to many of Massillon’s compositions. I continued to read Robinson’s character of Jesus; which containing more than a one volume of itself is a larger work, than any of the others, and appears to have something more in it.— I did not write this Evening.

18. Mr: Woodward and Captain Towne visited me this morning. The Captain does not expect to go so soon as he supposed he should when here before. I went to the shop of Mr: Etter, the Mineralogist, Antiquarian, Jeweller and Bookseller to see some of his books— He told me that he had procured a place for Captain Symonds as a tutor, to take care of children in some house— As I was walking afterwards I met first Mr: Navarro, who told me that Count Chernicheff had arrived last Night from Paris— I afterwards met Count Lüxbourg who was going to dine at Baron Blome’s and I walked with him. He thinks that Russia is about to adopt decidedly a system of neutrality, and speaks of a new Ukaze for the regulation of trade which is to be issued next Sunday the anniversary of the Emperor’s accession— I do not much believe in that— Luxbourg told me that his letters from Count Montgelas the Bavarian Minister of foreign Affairs informed him that all their advices from Paris concurred in stating that the coolness between France and Russia, was becoming more and more notorious; but that hopes were entertained it would not come to an absolute rupture this Season.— He says that the Emperor Napoleon scarcely speaks to Prince Kurakin, and that Monsieur de Champagny has had quite an angry conversation with Mr: Nesselrode, at a public dinner and before a large Company— Yesterday the Ambassador dined with the Emperor, who after dinner was in Conference with him untill 10. O’Clock; and this day the Ambassador has been engaged writing, and has admitted nobody.— In the mean time both parties continue to arm and prepare for War— There are now at least two hundred thousand men stationed on the frontier from Riga to Kiew, and yesterday or the day before 180 heavy Cannon were sent off from this City, in addition to all those that had been sent before— On the other hand France has just sent a large quantity of fire-arms to Dantzick and to Warsaw; and the number of troops under arms in the Duchy of Warsaw, is from fifty to sixty thousand men.— I pass’d the Evening in my chamber—wrote a little; and finished the Continuation of Bossuet’s Discourse upon Universal History.— It is a mere chronological index of Events from the year 800 to 1660.— Materials for a Continuation of the Discourse, and so different from it that they are hardly worth reading. Even in these minutes however the partiality of the writer is glaring, in every thing that concerns religion. The manner in which he speaks of Wicliff—of John Huss—of Luther, Zuinglius, Calvin and the massacre of St: Bartholomew, shews how much more vehement his zeal is against a mere opinion which he deems a heresy, than against the most detestable crimes committed in support of his Cause.

19. Mr Kenyon called on me this morning to make enquiries respecting the Vessel to which he belongs—the Venus— I was not able to answer them. A Sailor from the vessel which Captain Jewett lost in November last was here to ask for relief. Met and walked again with Count Lüxbourg; but he had learnt nothing of importance since yesterday. In the Evening I read in the first Volume of Tooke’s View of the Russian Empire during the Reign of Catherine the second, and to the close of the eighteenth Century.— It is a compilation, and the first Book being intituled the Natural State of the Empire, the principal contributors to it are Pallas, Gmelin and Guldenstaedt.— We closed the Evening at Cards.— I met in the Streets this day several Droshkies for the first time this Season. The thaw has continued almost without interruption a full fortnight and more. The Season is now about two months in advance of the same time last year— There is scarcely snow and ice enough left in the streets to make them passable in sledges

20. The weather continues warm and beautiful—the thermometer in the sun at 74 of Fahrenheit— The blocks of ice, which are now carrying from the river and the Canals to fill the ice-cellars have shrunk from their usual dimensions of four or five feet thick to less than three, and run in streams as they pass through the Streets— There are few sledges to be seen— I had the morning without interruption, and wrote— Madame de Betancourt and her daughters pass’d the Evening with our Ladies; and we had also a visit from Count Lüxbourg. I had therefore no leisure for reading, and was obliged to postpone the further perusal of Tooke’s View of the Russian Empire.

21. A Diplomatic dinner of about sixty persons at the French Ambassador’s.— The Chancellor, great Crown-Officers, Generals and foreign Ministers were there; all in full dress. Immediately after I went in Baron Campenhausen came to me and told me that it was better late than never; that he had been upwards of a fortnight upon pins, untill yesterday which had been the first day that he had been able to make his report to the Emperor— That he was happy now to say that the cases of all the American vessels (excepting that of the Eliza at Archangel) were definitively decided— That the Cargoes and parts of Cargoes, which had not the necessary certificates should be admitted, on the engagement of the persons interested in them to produce the Certificates hereafter— That as to all the other small parcels, which were under other circumstances of irregularity, the Emperor had also ordered that they also should be admitted, and that thus every thing recognized as American should be cleared— With regard to the case of the Eliza, there might be some further delay— A Gentleman who had some interest in it, had called upon him once or twice; but could speak nothing but English; which he the Baron could not speak; and therefore they had found some difficulty in understanding one another.— That however he had already written his opinion, that the case was very strongly distinguishable from those of the pretended Teneriff vessels which were condemned and confiscated here last Summer—and the business would be eventually terminated to my satisfaction.— I thanked the Baron for his information, and especially for the final decision upon the cases which had been in suspense— And I asked him whether the Custom-House had received the orders for the admission of the merchandizes— He said that they would be expedited from the Commission for neutral Navigation to-morrow or the next day, and that he had told Mr: Stieglitz eight or ten days ago, that he might freely make advances upon the goods as much as if they were already admitted.— At table I sat between Count Bussche, and the French Consul Mr: Lesseps, and had conversation with both of them. Mr: Lesseps was in affliction; he had left an infant child at home, at the point of death; by convulsions which had been followed by a violent fever— He did not expect it would live through the day— He had sent the Ambassador an excuse this morning, and had concluded to come only as the child had two or three hours of sleep which continued when he left home.— Count Bussche told me that A Courier was gone the day before yesterday to recall General Kamensky from the command of the army in Turkey, and that General Kutusoff the Master of the Police was appointed to go and take his place. I asked him what was the cause of this change—he said he did not know— Perhaps to employ Kamensky upon a more important command. He said that Chernicheff, who was himself present at the dinner had brought a letter from the Emperor Napoleon to the Emperor Alexander, expressed in terms of friendship and kindness stronger than any that he had ever written before— But that there were other things which did not so well correspond to these professions— He also remarked that there were many of the Ministers and Generals here whom he did not know— That they were never seen only upon these great dinners, or at Court, and that if you asked who they were you seldom found any body who could tell you.— He said that his king (Jerom) had a curiosity to know characters, and had given him instructions to report particulars respecting the most distinguished persons at this Court— But he had excused himself from executing this Commission— It was too difficult; and too dangerous.— The king had beaucoup d’esprit—but he was a young man, and perhaps had not altogether reflected upon the possible consequences of things— For his part he made it a principle to write nothing but what he might be prepared in the vicissitudes of this world to have all reported back here again— We talked also of the apparent avowal in the late French official Gazettes of the intention to annex all Spain to the French Empire— Prince Dolgoruki, who has just been appointed Minister to Naples, and who sat on the other side of Count Bussche took part in this Conversation, which he observed must be spoken in such a tone of voice that the Ambassador should not hear it. Mr: d’Alopeus sat next to the Prince. He too is appointed Minister to the king of Wurtemberg; but with a permission to visit all the Courts of the Rhenish Confederation— Luxbourg supposes, to be a spy upon all their movements in these critical times— After dinner I conversed with General Ouvaroff, who has just returned from the Turkish army, and with Count Alexander Soltykoff, who told me that the last census, or as they call it here Revision of the Empire was in the year 1795 or 1796; which was taken, before the regular period, which is at intervals of twenty years, on account of the final division of Poland, with the annexation of the Polish Provinces to the Empire— The Ambassador was apparently in a good humour, and his guests seemed more at his ease than they have appeared at some of his late parties; but the extraordinary attention paid by them to Count St: Julien, the Austrian Envoy was remarkable— Excepting the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff, whom the Ambassador himself attended, all the other principal Ministers and Generals made a
stand at the door untill the Count passed to go in to dinner. The Count was quite irradiated with this politeness; and bowed himself almost into a hoop as he step’d from the Circle to precede them— He sat at the Ambassador’s left hand at table. The Grand Chamberlain Narishkin told me that he had come last week from Moscow, where he had seen Mr: Harris— I told Count Romanzoff that Mr: Harris was very much pleased with Moscow, on which he said cela ne me contrarie point du tout, d’entendre qu’on s’amuse à Moscow— Cela ne me contrarie point du tout is a phrase of the Counts to signify that it gives him great pleasure— I came home quite early this Evening, and pass’d the remainder of it in conversation, and at Cards.

22. Morning visit from Mr: Fisher and Mr: Lynch— A return of the Cold weather brought me with it some rhumatic pains— Madame de Betancourt was going to a Concert given by Steibelt, at the Hall of the Phil-harmonic Society— She had two spare tickets, and offered them to our Ladies, who declined accepting them— She then sent and offered me one of them which I accepted. The Concert was indifferent— An Overture of Cherubini— A Song from the Opera of Cinderilla (a Quartetto) of Steibelt’s own composition, & performed by singers from the German Theatre— A Duet upon the Piano and the Harp; executed by Steibelt and a Madame Beck— The instruments were not in tune—a Quartetto from Mozart’s enchanted flute—concluded by a fancy piece of Steibelt’s, performed on the Piano by himself— The whole was so dull that I found it not easy to defend myself from sleep— After the Concert I attended Madame de Betancour to her Carriage, and then returned home— Read part of Atala, by Chateaubriand, which has been lent me by Mr: Prevost.

23. Mr: Montreal, the Chevalier de Navarro, Mr: Dana, and Mr: Moses successively called upon me this morning— Mr: Navarro told me that the General appointed to command the army in Turkey in the room of General Kamensky, was not the Master of the Police Kutusoff, who is only a Major-General, but the old General Kutusoff, who has already once commanded that army.— Mr: Dana proposes to set out on Tuesday for Moscow.— As I was returning from my walk about five O’Clock I met the Carriage of the Empress-Mother, followed by two others, just going from the Palace, and I saw them cross the river from the marble Palace over to the fortress, at the Church of which she annually goes and performs a solemn act of devotion at the tomb of the late Emperor Paul; this Night being the anniversary of his death. I had intended to have gone over and witnessed this Ceremony; but on speaking of it to the Master of Ceremonies Maisonneuve he spoke of it in terms rather dissuading me to go.— He said it was a mere act of family devotion, at which he had never attended himself, and he could not tell me the hour at which it took place— Mr: Harris however had mentioned it to me as an object of curiosity worthy of being seen.— But now it was too late to follow the imperial carriages over, and I was returning home to dinner.— About 7 in the Evening Mr: Harris called upon us, and passed the remainder of it with us— He had arrived about two hours before from Moscow. He has been very much gratified with his tour to Archangel and to the antient Metropolis of the Empire; which has been nearly a month longer than he intended when he left this place.— Catherine has been unwell and confined to her chamber all this day.

24. This day is the anniversary of the Emperor’s accession and commences the eleventh year of his reign— But he never distinguishes it as a festival. I pass’d the morning in writing— Mr: Harris dined and spent the Evening with us— He had met the Emperor upon the Quay, and had been as much gratified with his interview with his Majesty, as with the numerous attentions and distinctions shewn him upon his Journey.— I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the use of the ecclesiastical revenues; which is very good— The doctrine is at least sufficiently rigorous; and he warns his clergy with great earnestness against all luxurious indulgences, and against all selfish parsimony. The principle which he assumes is that all ecclesiastical revenues are merely trusts for the relief of the Poor, which ought to be applied faithfully to their destined purposes, and of which the clergy are only depositories for distribution— That the proportion of them which they can apply to their own purposes, is only that which they can claim as Poor, and that it is a scandalous abuse to appropriate any part of them for ostentation, for sensual indulgences, for the pride of birth or family, or to accumulate a patrimony for their kindred— He complains however that these rules are universally disregarded and violated. I read also two Sections of Robinson’s character of Christ— They refer to the Conference with Nicodemus, and to the interview with the Samaritan woman at the Well— The doctrine of Regeneration comes under consideration in the former of these two Sections— Robinson urges and insists upon it without making it intelligible and seemingly without understanding it himself— He speaks however of it as containing the Quintessence of the whole system of Christianity— I wrote nothing this Evening; and have lost several successive days in this respect.

25. The Emperor left the City very early this morning, upon a visit to his Sister at Twer— At the same time he dispatched Count Chernicheff, on a new mission to Paris.— Mr: Krehmer sent me a number of English newspapers; (Courier’s) from 23. Feby: to the first of this month— They contain accounts from the United States to 30. January; only 54 days ago—which is the shortest time within which I have heard from America, since we have been in this Country.— I was employed the whole morning, and untill three in the afternoon reading these Papers— Mr: Dana dined with us— At the close of the Evening we had cards— I finished reading Ataia, and began that of Réné— I met in my walk this day Mr: Prevost who turned and walked with me— We conversed upon French Literature, and he mentioned to me that it was Mr: Caillard who introduced him first into the Department of foreign Affairs. He told me some Circumstances of that Gentleman’s last years— And the History of Mr: Chateaubriand’s Itinerary from Paris to Jerusalem, which was published the second of this month, and which he has just received.

26. Mr: Harris called on me this morning, and afterwards came and dined with us. I mentioned to him the despatches which during his absence I have received from America— He shewed me a letter which he has received from a Mr: John Speyer at Stockholm who informs him that he is accredited as commercial Agent of the United States in Sweden— General Watzdorf and Count Bose, and Mr: and Mrs: Krehmer, and their eldest daughter pass’d the Evening with us— Mr: Krehmer spoke to me of a Panegyric upon Count Romanzoff which had lately appeared; and promised to send me the petition of the merchants for licences— Walking before dinner I met General Pardo, both going out and returning; the second time he had two copies of his Greek translations from Horace, which he had just taken at his Bookbinders— He promised to send me a copy of this work.

27. Morning visit from Mr: Montréal, who told me that the Ambassador had informed him the Emperor had rejected the petition that licences might be granted for vessels to come with Cargoes to the Russian Ports. Mr: Dana called likewise and took a Passport from me— He goes for Moscow to-morrow morning. I employed the greatest part of the day in writing; and this Evening after a week’s interruption wrote again a page of short-hand— Resumed also the reading of Tooke’s View of the Russian Empire, which is very dull, and finished that of Chateaubriand’s Réné, which is very flighty.— This writer is now in high fashion in France; but I have not before read any of his works— In these I find some original Genius, but too much of exaggeration not to say Bombast.

28. Mr: Colombi died this morning about 7. O’Clock— He has been ill with a schirrous liver, and a dropsy consequent upon it for many months, although the dangerous or rather incurable nature of his disease was not known untill some days after we spent the Evening at his house; which was the closing day of the last year; old Style— I called upon Mr: Navarro, and had half an hour’s conversation with him. He seems to expect that Russia will commence an offensive War against France; in which I believe him to be mistaken.— I rose this morning very early and in the course of the day wrote one or two short letters— Read also much in the newspapers; which I consider as time lost— It was a day of leisure, which I seldom have at present— Letter-writing and Journalizing occupies almost all my time. The Evening was divided between Short-hand, Tooke’s Russia, and Cards.

29. This morning I received two letters from a young Mr: Farley in London, enclosing one from Mr: Gray of Boston, and one from my brother, the first that I have received from any part of my family for nearly six Months— It is dated 24. September last— It is probable that I shall not have very soon another day of leisure— But I was employed all the morning to little purpose; and the Evening to none at-all. Mr: Harris dined, and spent part of the Evening with us. It was of course not an Evening of occupation.

30. I had a morning visit from Mr: Woodward, and Mr: Moses, who is going to Riga. I wasted the morning I scarcely know how. We all received invitations from Madame Colombi, and from Mr: Francis Colombi to attend the funeral of their husband and brother on Monday Morning 10. O’Clock at the Catholic Church. In the Evening I read part of the first Volume of Tooke’s View of Russia, and intended to have written a page— But the Gazettes came in, and a letter from Mr: Hazard at Copenhagen, which employed the Evening hours untill eleven, and I gave up the writing for this day; or in other words procrastinated.— We have now the first Supplement to the Winter— My thermometer at the window stood at 7 degrees below 0 of Reaumur, which corresponds with 10 of the Academy’s Register— The coldest exposition is that of the North-East— Mine is nearly West— The difference in the extremest colds is from 5 to 6 degrees— About the freezing point from one to two— And at the intervals, in a gradual proportion.

31. Morning visit from Mr: Fisher with Mr: Richard Smith of Philadelphia, and Mr Andrew Cunningham junr: of Boston; both from Archangel and Moscow.— Mr: Smith came with Mr: Harris, and Mr Cunningham some days after them— After writing tomy brother, I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the conduct suitable to Ecclesiastics in the World. Like that upon the management of the Revenues it lays down rigorous principles— If the Catholic Clergy had practiced upon them at all times there never would have been any occasion for a Protestant reformation— Perhaps the very severity of the Rule was one principal cause of its being almost universally violated. I read also this Evening two sections of Robinson’s character of Christ.— The Ladies visited Madame Colombi.— Fahrenheit’s thermometer this morning at 0.— Mrs: A. pass’d the Evening at Madame de Betancourt’s.

Day. Differs little from that of the last Month— I rise however earlier— Usually about 8. and sometimes by 6. On the other hand I give smaller portions of the Evening to any serious occupations and more frequently abandon the whole evening to company or to Amusement. The proportion of the day given to study or business remains about the same; and the share of interruption by visits received or paid differs but little.
